column2: Aurora 2, come in! This is the landing party, come in!
Aurora 2 listening, go ahead.
Captain, sir… There is no life on this planet. Not on the surface, not below it. But the scanners have gone haywire! Captain, it seems that they react to stones that way…
Stones?!
Sir, yes, sir! We are registering some kind of alpha waves and biorhythms from some rocks. What do we do, Captain? Do we bring one of the rocks onboard?
It's weird… I have to contact the Science Department. Wait… Gordon! Can you hear me?
C-Captain? *Gordon looks a bit unkempt, the collar of his shirt is covered in… is that mustard?*
We have a small problem with this planet. And also you have some mustard on your collar.
It's not mustard, it's agar. *Gordon snorts and waves it off.* What's the problem, sir?
Stones. The soldiers say the scanners register their brain waves and biorhythms. Looks like our ship scanner clocked them too.
Uhhh… Sapient? Live rocks, C-Captain?
Looks like it… We need to make a choice: either we bring one of the rocks onboard for analysis or not.

*Gordon opens his mouth to answer but cuts himself off.* They... hm... if they're alive, that's one thing. What if they're sentient? That's another thing entirely. A v-v-very complicated question, C-Captain. Do we dare taking a sentient being from its homeplanet without asking? *He rubs the bridge of his nose.* If it really is sentient, that is.
Alive or sentient… What does it matter? They're just rocks.
Discussing ethics? I thought your love for vivisection would be stronger.
So what do we do?
I think I know what to do.

I understand, C-Captain, it's not easy to accept a rock as sentient, buuuut... *Gordon stutters and scratches the back of his head absentmindedly.* What if they're sentient and we take one of them? It'll be kidnapping a real personality, a peaceful hum- a creature! That's most... *He screws up his face.* Antiscientific!
Antiscientific? I remember Unit 731 from the academic history classes.
*Gordon loses his confidence completely and mumbles something about new times, humanism, and compassion.
Discussing ethics? I thought your love for vivisection would be stronger.
So what do we do?
I think I know what to do.
I'm a scientist, C-Captain. Not a barbarian.
That never stopped you from performing autopsies on some sentient creatures.
Corpses. I can autopsy a dead Klisk, Bork, human for studying… Killing them for this? *Gordon shakes his head no.*
Alive or sentient… What does it matter? They're just rocks.
So what do we do?
I think I know what to do.
It's that time, C-Captain, where I absolve myself of all responsibility and put it on you. I follow your orders. I'll agree to whatever you say.
That's not very fair Gordon.
You're the boss. I'm not. *Gordon rubs his nose and lowers his eyes for a couple of seconds.*
Alive or sentient… What does it matter? They're just rocks.
Discussing ethics? I thought your love for vivisection would be stronger.
I think I know what to do.

*After thinking it over for a bit, Gordon replies.* This is a good idea, C-Captain. Of course, there are risks... what if the stones turn out to be agressive? But... I think that's a good proposition. *He nods.*
Alive or sentient… What does it matter? They're just rocks.
Discussing ethics? I thought your love for vivisection would be stronger.
So what do we do?
I think I know what to do.
In that case you don't need me, Captain? *Gordon walks away without even turning offhis camera. You can see right away how he chews someone out, waving his hands.*
Landing party, do you copy?
Sir?
Take one of the rocks onboard, we'll study it on the ship.
Pack up and leave, don't take anything with you.
Sir, yes, sir. Affirmative. *Click. Apparently, they've already started.*
